comments.commentBody: Grasp straw, hold on, pray as you go down for the third time.  Some strategy.

Once again, Nate Cohn writes an analysis, seemingly objective, that has as its underlying theme how Donald Trump won't become the Republican nominee. He doesn't state it explicitly, but ever since Trump entered the race for the nomination, Cohn and other pundits have dismissed the likelihood of his becoming the nominee. Now that he has taken the plurality of votes in two primaries and the Nevada caucuses, Cohn and others are forced to acknowledge the appeal Trump has for a sizable proportion of the electorate. But instead of writing a column titled "how a sweep of Super Tuesday brings Trump closer to the nomination", he writes instead how losing all Super Tuesday contests keeps Rubio competitive.

Cohn has been similarly dismissive of Bernie Sanders, writing about how the demographics of various States presuppose a Sanders victory or demonstrate why he can't win the nomination.

Apparently Nate Cohn has written off Ted Cruz and thinks the republican primary is solely between Trump and Rubio even before Super Tuesday is in the books.
Shouldn't Rubio at least win ONE state first?Texas has 155 delegates and it's highly unlikely Cruz will lose Texas.Although Trump has led all along,he still only has around 35% of the republican vote and Cruz has remained in second place nationally.Nate Cohn,this is NOT a 2 man race yet.
Politics, war by other means.  This is like a game of battleship, where the players can't see the board.

Rubio will not win Florida. He stabbed up in the back. He stood quiet and did nothing when his donor, Disney, replace hundreds of American programmers with cheaper foreign labor. We are not forgetting who Judas Rubio really is.

Cruz is an egomaniac who is likely to either win TX or come close. He already won IA and he doesn't care what his actions do to his party. He's not going to drop out. Rubio should drop out -- he hasn't won anything and isn't projected to anytime soon, if ever -- but his puppet-masters will keep him in rather than ceding the nomination to Trump.

Assuming Republicans don't overtly cheat and Trump wins the nomination it will be interesting to hear how his views change for the general election. Hillary Clinton is deeply unpopular and, as Bush and Sanders have shown, the US electorate isn't into dynasties or being bought by billionaires. Americans are still looking for Hope & Change: many haven't moved on from the effects of the financial crisis. The only person projecting the ability to make that happen, rightfully or wrongfully, is Trump.

MARCO RUBIO is an empty suit who has been purchased by several mega-billionaire donors whose foreign policy agenda concerning the Middle East is not in the best interests of the United States. This is something voters should be worrying about when they go to the polls.

replies.commentBody: @MPF in Chicago: Can't affect people's lives if you don't win and the way to win is to get the number of delegates needed. So, while the media actually does spend tons of time stating and analyzing candidates positions (and dreams and fantasies), the numbers game does tell an important story about whose vision will reach the White House for good or evil.

comments.commentBody: This article is a good example of how the media chooses to cover elections as if they were games or sports or mere meme-fodder rather than consequential events affecting all people.

all of the crazed xenophobia and trash talk in foreign policy is astonishing in its stupidity. but after the fearmongering and warmaking of W-43, it seems clear that the gop is as bankrupt in its understanding of global politics as it is bankrupt and tawdry in its sense of what domestic governance means. malfesance and selfinterested power seem to be the prime motivators. the only idea driven candidate is unelectable former independent from vt. the door is wide open for mrs. clinton. let's hope she gets in touch with the sense of moral responsibility she had in the late 60s in the exercise of leadership.

This is a bit interesting but there are obvious problems-

Losing every or even most states on March 1 will shatter what ever momentum Rubio has and destroy the morale of the donors and volunteers

More importantly, how is Rubio going to lose all these states and then turn it around? It would be interesting if there was some evidence to back it up like him polling well in the latter contests. The truth is that Rubio is down 20 points in his home state. How can that change in three weeks? These voters already know Rubio very well and they don't like him

Is Rubio leading in Michigan, Missouri, Illinois, Ohio or Pennsylvania? If he was, this theory would have a lot of merit. Instead, he trails in everyone, often by large margins,

This is like saying "If Rubio loses every state to Hillary, the electoral college might vote him in" Technically true, but totally unrealistic

This is all interesting about Mr. Rubio.  But it gives short shrift to Cruz.  As this Trump University issues comes into focus, and it was Gov. Abbott, who as Attorney General shut it down in Texas, sorry, Trump does not win Texas.  And that is the bigger point.  Trump had to have had one of the worst debates ever.  Maybe Admiral Stockdale.  He got pummeled.  This anti- immigration stuff is all a lie.  He lied about Libya.  He had earlier lied about Iraq.  He lied about the IRS.  Everything he says is a lie, and he bought no ads.  In short, this is not about Rubio.  It's about Trump, who looks very much like Wile E. Coyote.  Scenarios of a strong Trump are ignoring a drastically changed situation now that Rubio and Cruz have finally decided to go negative.  And have money.  That should be what people like Mr. Cohn are writing about.  Now, when this is all over, why Bush never dropped all this Polish, Trump Ties, Mar a Lago stuff on him needs to be explained.  That is just freaking weird.  What was Bush thinking?

Anybody else fed up with the Electoral College continuing to hijack pure democracy which should be based on winning the majority of the popular vote?

Anybody else see delegates as the greatest threat to democracy when they have the power to not vote with the voice of the majority popular vote?

Anybody else see the need for one national primary without delegates on the same day in March to elect the candidates from the contenders within each party and those who win the majority popular vote to go forward in the general election in Nov ?

Because after watching Moe, Larry and Curly in Houston last night I don't think the sane part of the viewing public can take much more....

Rubio's path to victory starts with this
http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2016/02/26/pony-unicorn-po...
Start by catching the Unicorn Marco

replies.commentBody: I completely agree - Chritie was in the bag the whole time
Redstate.com has piece on Rubio campaign strategy possibly angling for brokered convention if can pick up enough delegates on Super Tuesday

comments.commentBody: This article is fanciful. The race is frankly over. I'm surprised the NYT seems to be missing what happened today. Christie was the RNC attack dog against Trump he was the leader of the Republican governors association. That means he was there and helped construct the current establishment roadmap that was designed to give Jeb the nomination. His overt endorsement of Trump today means he was a mole. He was Trump's mole. Let that sink in. If you think I'm wrong fair enough. However do please think of me kindly if I'm right...;-)
How many people think this column will be followed up by one titled "How Bernie Sanders Could Lose Every State on Super Tuesday and Still Win"?

replies.commentBody:
@Fooose: Isn't it too late to start a third party run? Ross Perot announced his intentions for 3rd party in February 1992, and needed time to start the organization. If Trump waits until contested convention becomes likely, it may be too late for him.

Besides, to most Trump supporters electabiliy is much more important than policy issues. They want to win and get the liberal dems out of white house first; the policiy matters can be negotiated later.

comments.commentBody: I'd like to point out the contingency the bean counters are missing- a contested convention in Rubio's favor could induce Trump to run 3rd party.  The Donald is making himself out to be Achilles in this Achean crises.
Republican primaries are starting to look like the tour de France where the overall  winner doesn't win a single stage.

replies.commentBody:
Mr Trump will not be beholden to any donor except the American people? That's baloney. He's beholden to one single donor, Mr Trump himself, and that's what makes him very dangerous.

So far only Bernie Sanders is beholden to the American people.

He also seems to move from one job to another fairly quickly seemingly to me to avoid being detected as lazy and is forced out.  He has a history of financial sloppiness and he does have a dependency on a benefactor.  He will also run away from a position if there is much opposition.  Pandering in the way he does comes in one form of being emphatic he is this or that depending on the direction of the political wind.  What I heard hims say  was that he comes close to denying he was significantly involved on the "Gang of Eight" and supportive of positions conservatives oppose.  I suspect that one thing he had in mind was the possibility of gaining Hispanic support and bringing them into the Republican Party if he supported immigration reform.  It backfired.  How supportive of Mr. Rubio could Hispanics be when he runs away from an issue important to so many?  Completely unprepared for the job and has the support of panicking mainstream Republicans.

comments.commentBody:
Rubio is inexperienced and lacks presidential traits. He is beholden to his big money donors unlike Mr Trump.

Mr Trump will not be beholden to any donor except the American pepole who votes for him. But go Hilary! Go Bernie!

replies.commentBody:
"Rubio is not running for another senate term..."

Because Florida law prohibits a candidate from appearing twice on the same ballot. Rubio cannot run for re-election to the Senate and vie for the presidency/vice presidency in November.

For once, I think Florida's position on an electoral matter is correct.
Baloney. Rubio made his money from a book.

comments.commentBody:
Rubio is as corrupt as he claims Trump to be . Rubio , a graduate of a bottom feeder law school, never made much money until he was given a job at about a half million a year by a firm that does government lobbying , consulting and contracting and he got this job while he was in the Florida legislature. I detect crony capitalism if not outright bribery. Trump says that Rubio bought a house and then sold it soon after to a lobbyist who paid him about double what he paid .Rubio is not running for another senate term even though he is unlikely to be nominated for president. Is he planning to cash in on being in the senate and also running for president and make millions?
Rubio lied to voters in order to get elected to the Senate. He assured them that he was against a path to citizenship ( amnesty) for illegals when he ran and as soon as he was elected he joined the gang of 8 in their amnesty bill.

replies.commentBody: Clinton is not being crammed down anyone's throats, she is breathtakingly popular among Democrats. She is on the path towards being *elected* by at-large Democrats.

Saying Clinton is 'breathtakingly popular' when a tremendous percentage of her once guaranteed electorate not only flocks to her opposition, but have for her a sour taste considering the way she is using wall streat money to muscle a more sincere candidate, shows how surprising her loss will be to long time supporters of the Clinton dynasty.

She is being "crammed down our throats." The people who were calling it the "coronation" were correct. The Clinton's and the DNC were shocked when Bernie started gaining traction and still doing everything they can to stop him. Not to worry, on election day in November I will do my liberal duty and pull the lever for HRC. The DNC doesn't get that like the Repubs. we are sick of the establishment giving everything away to the wealthy who own the politicians.

comments.commentBody:
Rubio is being crammed down the throat of the Republicans, and Clinton is being crammed down the throat of the Democrats. Both parties do it the same way, with fear and the rolling out of endorsements to make it seem that resistence is futile. I say a pox on both their houses!

We are sick, sick, sick of politics as usual. We will need a whole lot more in terms of bread and circuses to mollified us this time. The elites get the bread; the rest of us get the circuses. Enough is enough is enough!

replies.commentBody: Kasich is not a Republican . He thinks big government and big taxes  are what we need to solve our economic ills
You looked at Kasich's role as governor?  Are you sure you didn't get confused and mean "Trump?"

comments.commentBody: I agree with Tom C. Trump-Kasich is the best bet. And if I was in the head of Republican party instead of making fun of mr. Trump, I would help him to become the best candidate possible. If Trump doesn't get the nomination, he'll run as an independent and the Republican party is going to loose all these votes. Each moment in history asks for different kind of leader. I'm sure there is more prepared candidates but the moment ask for someone as mr. Trump.

It's time for Rubio to embrace his Catholicism;forget the Evangelicals and pray to St. Jude.  This would all be so delicious (including last night's debate) if only I could forget one of these people might become our President...

replies.commentBody: Conservatives believe that big government makes everything more expensive and less efficient and that the private sector is what  fixed the economy . Conservatives are for small government not no government . The depression of 1929 was made worse and lasted longer because of government programs like the TVA. Did you ever visit a communist country back in their day ?
Jill, you need some lessons in American history, especially in regards to the depression. It was big government spending that ended the depression.

comments.commentBody: Someone needs to define "conservative." What, exactly, do Republicans mean when they say "conservative" and how would they play this out in real life--aside from destructive racist behavior and failure to tend the farm, feed the animals, plow the furrows, etc. How and what is the purpose of their party in today's world? Government, being unnecessary and they wishing to "drown it in a bathtub", what is the reason for the existence of the Republican Party? What is their aim? What is their goal? And, finally, how will we know when they get there?

it sure seems like the NYTimes is stealthily backing Rubio, in an attempt to derail Trump. To me that seems like deciding that a rattlesnake is a better house pet than a black mamba.

Both candidates policy goals are positively odious, and both roughly the same - anti immigration, shred the Iran deal, shred Obamacare "on day 1" , etc.

It's just Rubio, being an insider , would stand slightly more chance at doing it. and that alone makes him more dangerous than the bombastic Trump.

replies.commentBody: Oh yea, a junior Senator who has not accomplished anything significant....  can we think or any other recent presidential candidates who fit that description....  Like perhaps President O.

comments.commentBody: Rubio is not going to win. He is a junior senator who has not accomplished anything significant, in part because he has been running for President since the day he was elected to the Senate. He might be an interesting presidential candidate 20 years from now, or he might turn out to be nothing more than a huge ego with a pretty face. Personally I would like to see Trump-Kasich on the ticket. Kasich would add the experience and moderation that would appeal to a broad swath of moderates and win the general election. I applaud Kasich's courage to accept the medicaid expansion in Ohio for the good of the people, rather than hewing to the tea-party line.
